title: Will vs Be Going To: Future Forms
summary: This lesson explains the differences between 'will' and 'be going to' for expressing future actions, focusing on predictions and decisions.
content: Both 'will' and 'be going to' can express future actions but with different meanings.
'Will' is used for predictions based on opinion and instant decisions.
'Be going to' is used for predictions based on evidence and pre-made plans.
The choice between them depends on the context and the speaker's intention.

examples: I think he'll win the election.
He will be a good doctor.
rules.notes: Used when the speaker thinks something will happen

rules.rule: Be going to (predictions based on present evidence)
examples: Don't drive like that! We're going to have an accident!
The doctor said I'm going to have a girl.
rules.notes: Used when there's visible evidence something will happen

rules.rule: When both are possible (with slight difference in meaning)
examples: The conference starts in 10 minutes. We are going to be late. (visible evidence)
We need to hurry up. We'll be late for the conference. (personal opinion)

rules.rule: Will (instant decisions made at speaking moment)
examples: 'We don't have sugar.' 'Don't worry, I'll buy some.'
'Why are you undressing?' 'Because I'm going to go for a swim.'
'I'm going to visit my parents this weekend.'
'Sarah needs to talk to you.' 'Oh, I'll call her now.' (just decided)
'Sarah needs to talk to you.' 'Yes, I'm going to call her.' (already planned)

tips: Use 'will' when you're making a promise, offer, or instant decision
Use 'be going to' when you can see the future event coming (evidence)
For personal plans you've already made, use 'be going to'
In informal speech, 'going to' often becomes 'gonna'
Remember: 'will' doesn't change form ('he will', not 'he wills')
common_errors: Incorrect: 'I think it's going to rain tomorrow.' (no evidence) Correct: 'I think it will rain tomorrow.'
Incorrect: 'Look at those clouds! It will rain!' Correct: 'Look at those clouds! It's going to rain!'
Incorrect: 'I'll study medicine next year.' (pre-planned) Correct: 'I'm going to study medicine next year.'
